texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Working remotely involves lots of meetings in challenging home conditions and I love noise-canceling bluetooth headphones for meetings and music. It really helps me focus. However, as anyone knows who works with multiple audio devices on the same machine, getting all of the inputs and outputs working properly for each application is tedious. 😅
texts.text: Working remotely involves lots of meetings in challenging home conditions and I love noise-canceling bluetooth headphones for meetings and music. It really helps me focus. However, as anyone knows who works with multiple audio devices on the same machine, getting all of the inputs and outputs working properly for each application is tedious. 😅

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The last thing I want to wrestle with (as a scramble to a meeting) is redirecting audio from my speakers to my headphones in PulseAudio. 😱
texts.text: The last thing I want to wrestle with (as a scramble to a meeting) is redirecting audio from my speakers to my headphones in PulseAudio. 😱

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, there's a pulseaudio module for that!
texts.text: Luckily, there's a pulseaudio module for that!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Goal
texts.text: Goal

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's what I want:
texts.text: Here's what I want:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Headphones turn on, connect via Bluetooth, and the default audio sink (output) should switch to the headphones
texts.text: Headphones turn on, connect via Bluetooth, and the default audio sink (output) should switch to the headphones

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The input (source) should not change (I have a separate microphone on the desk)
texts.text: The input (source) should not change (I have a separate microphone on the desk)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When the headphones turn off and disconnect, the audio should shift back to the original default
texts.text: When the headphones turn off and disconnect, the audio should shift back to the original default

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Enabling the module
texts.text: Enabling the module

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This was working really well on my desktop, but I recently switched to  Fedora Silverblue . I forgot how I dealt with this before.
texts.text: This was working really well on my desktop, but I recently switched to  Fedora Silverblue . I forgot how I dealt with this before.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A quick search led to an  Arch Linux forum post . The pulseaudio module  module-switch-on-connect  handles this automatically without extra configuration.
texts.text: A quick search led to an  Arch Linux forum post . The pulseaudio module  module-switch-on-connect  handles this automatically without extra configuration.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start some music, disconnect the bluetooth headphones, and load the module:
texts.text: Start some music, disconnect the bluetooth headphones, and load the module:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: $ pactl load-module module-switch-on-connect
texts.text: $ pactl load-module module-switch-on-connect

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Power on your headphones and wait for the connection. Audio should switch to your bluetooth headset automatically. Power off the bluetooth headphones and audio should shift back to the original source (perhaps your computer speakers).
texts.text: Power on your headphones and wait for the connection. Audio should switch to your bluetooth headset automatically. Power off the bluetooth headphones and audio should shift back to the original source (perhaps your computer speakers).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If that didn't work, you might need to tinker with your default audio sinks or add some udev rules to ensure your bluetooth headphones come up with the right sink. The  Arch Linux pipewire docs  provide a few options.
texts.text: If that didn't work, you might need to tinker with your default audio sinks or add some udev rules to ensure your bluetooth headphones come up with the right sink. The  Arch Linux pipewire docs  provide a few options.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Make it persistent
texts.text: Make it persistent

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Loading the module with
texts.text: Loading the module with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: pactl
texts.text: pactl

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: only works until pulseaudio is restarted or the machine reboots. You can make it persistent by adding it to your window manager's startup scripts.
texts.text: only works until pulseaudio is restarted or the machine reboots. You can make it persistent by adding it to your window manager's startup scripts.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I use i3/sway, so my configuration line looks like this:
texts.text: I use i3/sway, so my configuration line looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec_always --no-startup-id pactl load-module module-switch-on-connect
texts.text: exec_always --no-startup-id pactl load-module module-switch-on-connect
